study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) in treating COVID-19, focusing on outcomes such as SOFA score and 30-day all-cause mortality.
results_summary: The single RCT on ALA found no statistically significant differences between the intervention and placebo groups in SOFA score or 30-day all-cause mortality, suggesting limited efficacy in COVID-19 treatment.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients (specific inpatient/outpatient status not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) could inhibit ferroptosis and improve pregnancy outcomes in unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss (URPL) by targeting the PPARγ/NRF2/GPX4 pathway.
results_summary: The study found that ALA treatment mitigated PPARγ/NRF2/GPX4-mediated ferroptosis in URPL mouse models, suggesting it could be a promising therapeutic for improving pregnancy outcomes. Ferroptosis markers (ROS, MDA, GSH) and protein expression changes confirmed ALA's protective effect.
population_specificity: Patients with unexplained recurrent pregnancy loss (URPL) and murine models (CBA/J × DBA/2 and CBA/J × BALB/c mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of α-lipoic acid (α-LA) on sphingolipid metabolism and insulin signaling in rats with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: α-LA reduced sphinganine, dihydroceramide, and sphingosine levels while increasing ceramide levels. It also activated the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway, improving hepatic phosphorylation of Akt and mTOR, suggesting potential benefits for glucose intolerance and MASLD prevention.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats on a high-fat diet (HFD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of alpha-lipoic acid (LA) as a stabilizer for Ångstrom-scale gold particles (AuÅPs) conjugated with alendronate (AL) to enhance targeted bone delivery and therapeutic effects in osteoporosis.
results_summary: The study found that AuÅPs-AL significantly improved bone density and prevented bone loss in an osteoporosis mouse model, with no evidence of nanoparticle-associated toxicity. The results indicated enhanced osteogenesis and regulation of the WNT signaling pathway.
population_specificity: Osteoporosis mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) on menopausal obesity and its underlying mechanisms, particularly focusing on AMPK signaling and browning of white adipose tissue (WAT).
results_summary: ALA treatment significantly reduced body weight and WAT mass, improved plasma lipid profiles, enhanced UCP1 expression, and increased brown fat-specific markers in ovariectomized rats. In vitro, ALA reduced lipid accumulation and increased oxygen consumption, effects reversed by AMPK inhibition.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats (8 weeks old) subjected to bilateral ovariectomy (Ovx) and 3T3-L1 cells for in vitro study.
effective_dosage: 200 and 300 mg/kg/day (gavage) for rats; 100 and 250 μM for 3T3-L1 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism and effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) in reducing oxidative stress and improving recovery in rats with spinal cord injuries (SCI).
results_summary: ALA increased antioxidant capacity, reduced H2O2 levels, improved motor function (higher BBB scores), and promoted histological recovery in SCI rats. Transcriptome analysis revealed significant gene expression changes related to oxidative stress pathways.
population_specificity: Rats with moderate spinal cord contusion injuries.
effective_dosage: Intraperitoneal injection according to body weight (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze updated information on the use of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (αLA) from an anti-aging perspective, focusing on its protective and therapeutic roles in age-related disorders.
results_summary: The study found that αLA exhibits strong antioxidant properties, offering protective effects against age-related disorders such as neurodegeneration, metabolic disorders, cancers, nephropathy, infertility, and skin senescence. It showed particular promise in preventing Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population, with focus on age-related disorders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) to induce water stress tolerance in mungbean plants when applied exogenously through different modes.
results_summary: ALA treatment, particularly seed priming, improved growth and yield under water stress by enhancing photosynthetic pigments, plant water relations, antioxidant activity, and reducing oxidative damage. The highest benefits were observed at 0.1 and 0.15 mM ALA concentrations.
population_specificity: Mungbean plants (lines 16003 and 16004) under normal and reduced irrigation conditions.
effective_dosage: 0, 0.1, and 0.15 mM ALA applied via seed priming, foliar spray, or both.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) on hormonal and metabolic parameters in overweight/obese PCOS patients.
results_summary: ALA improved insulin sensitivity and reduced ALT/AST levels, with greater effects in patients with a familial diabetes background. No changes were observed in reproductive hormones.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese PCOS patients (n=32) not requiring hormonal treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) and the transcription factor ELK1 co-regulate erythroid and myeloid differentiation, potentially identifying a therapeutic target for myeloid leukemia.
results_summary: ALA promoted erythroid differentiation by targeting ELK1 in hematopoietic stem progenitor cells (HSPCs). Overexpression of ELK1 isoforms inhibited erythroid differentiation, while RNAseq analysis revealed distinct regulatory roles for L-ELK1 and S-ELK1 in neutrophil and hypoxia-related signaling.
population_specificity: CD34+ hematopoietic stem progenitor cells (HSPCs) and related progenitor cells in vitro and in NSG mice.
study_duration: 3 months post-transplantation in mice (in vitro duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of combining alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) with cisplatin and paclitaxel on ovarian cancer (OVCAR-3) cells, focusing on cell migration, invasion, and colony formation.
results_summary: The study found that ALA combined with cisplatin and paclitaxel significantly reduced RICTOR, MMP-9, and MMP-11 expressions, inhibited cell migration and invasion, and prevented colony formation in OVCAR-3 cells. ALA alone was ineffective, but the combination therapy showed promising results in reducing tumor cell adhesion and wound healing within 24 hours.
population_specificity: Ovarian cancer (OVCAR-3) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) could protect against prenatal cytarabine-induced hepatotoxicity in rat neonates.
results_summary: ALA co-administration ameliorated cytarabine-induced oxidative stress, biochemical changes, and histopathological abnormalities in rat pups, demonstrating protective effects against hepatotoxicity.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats (dams) and their female neonates (pups).
study_duration: From gestational day 8 to gestational day 21.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined supplementation of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) and mitoquinone (Mito Q) improves cardiac function and reduces inflammation and apoptosis in aged rats with myocardial infarction.
results_summary: The study found that ALA and Mito Q combined significantly improved cardiac function, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β), and decreased apoptotic markers (Bax, caspase-3, Cyt-c) and TUNEL-positive cells in aged rats with myocardial infarction.
population_specificity: Aged rats with induced myocardial infarction.
effective_dosage: ALA (100 mg/kg, gavage) and Mito Q (10 mg/kg, IP) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the solubility and stability of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (LA) by developing a nanofiber delivery system using methyl-beta-cyclodextrin and pullulan, and to evaluate its anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: The developed nanofibers showed enhanced physicochemical properties, rapid dissolution, and effective anti-inflammatory activity by reducing ROS, NO production, and pro-inflammatory cytokines in LPS-stimulated RAW 264.7 cells. The system also suppressed NF-ĸB nuclear translocation compared to free LA.
population_specificity: In vitro study using RAW 264.7 cells (murine macrophage cell line).
effective_dosage: 250 μM (LA concentration used in comparative analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) preconditioning, alone and in combination with mitoquinone (MitoQ), on cardioprotection following myocardial ischemia/reperfusion injury (IRI) in aged rats.
results_summary: The combination of ALA and MitoQ reduced oxidative stress, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, and infarct size, while improving mitochondrial function and dynamics in aged hearts subjected to IRI. The combined treatment showed greater efficacy than monotherapies in all measured parameters.
population_specificity: Aged male Wistar rats (22-24 months old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the molecular mechanism of α-lipoic acid (α-LA) in preventing prostate cancer (PCa) progression and its associated bone modulation.
results_summary: α-LA treatment significantly reduced PCa cell viability, migration, and invasion, increased ROS levels and HIF-1α expression, activated the JNK/caspase-3 pathway, and improved bone health by reducing PCa-mediated bone cell modulation.
population_specificity: Advanced human prostate cancer cell lines (PCa) and bone cells (MC3T3-E1 and BMMs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Alpha-Lipoic Acid, in combination with other supplements, could improve the resorption of subchorionic hematoma and alleviate symptoms in cases of threatened miscarriage.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significantly faster resorption of subchorionic hematoma and quicker reduction of symptoms (vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, uterine contractions) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (6th-13th week of gestation) with threatened miscarriage (subchorionic hematomas, pelvic pain/uterine contractions, and/or vaginal bleeding).
effective_dosage: 100 mg ALA (as part of a combination supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic efficacy of alpha-lipoic acid (α-LA) and caffeine-loaded chitosan nanoparticles (Caf-CNs) against cardiovascular complications induced by obesity in rats.
results_summary: Treatment with α-LA and/or Caf-CNs improved biochemical and histopathological alterations caused by obesity, demonstrating antilipemic, anti-atherogenic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) against oxaliplatin-induced peripheral neuropathy (OPN) in a zebrafish model.
results_summary: ALA significantly increased the number of axon bifurcations and intensity of MAGUK puncta compared to oxaliplatin alone, demonstrating protective effects against OPN. No significant difference was observed between ALA and epalrestat at 1 μM concentrations.
population_specificity: Tg(nbt:dsred) transgenic zebrafish with sensory nerves in the peripheral lateral line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of alpha-lipoic acid as a disease-modifying agent in people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that alpha-lipoic acid probably has little or no effect on neuropathy symptoms or adverse events at six months and may have little or no effect on impairment. The evidence was moderate to low certainty due to high risk of attrition bias.
population_specificity: Adults (aged 18 or older) with type 1 or type 2 diabetes and diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) on cardiometabolic risk factors and hormonal parameters in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly improved fasting blood sugar (FBS) and insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) in women with PCOS, but no significant differences were observed in other metabolic or hormonal parameters. The study concluded that ALA is an effective complementary therapy for managing PCOS.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) protects against bone loss in a combined model of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and postmenopausal osteoporosis (POP) by modulating the YAP/Glut4 pathway.
results_summary: ALA improved glucose tolerance, reduced oxidative stress and apoptosis, and alleviated bone loss in mice with T2DM and POP. The study identified the YAP/Glut4 pathway as a key mechanism in ALA's bone-protective effects.
population_specificity: Mice with induced T2DM and POP (high-fat diet + streptozocin + ovariectomy) and MC3T3-E1 cells treated with methylglyoxal.
effective_dosage: Not specified for in vivo study; in vitro study used ALA pretreatment for 24 hours (concentration not specified).
study_duration: 10 weeks for in vivo study; 24 hours for in vitro study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a rehabilitation program combined with Alpha-Lipoic Acid and other supplements in treating sciatica due to herniated discs, focusing on pain resolution, postural alterations, and quality of life.
results_summary: The Combo group (rehabilitation + supplements) showed statistically superior improvements in pain, disability, and quality of life at 30 days, and maintained superior results for pain and quality of life at 60 days compared to groups receiving only rehabilitation or supplements.
population_specificity: Young patients with sciatica due to herniated discs.
effective_dosage: 600 mg Alpha-Lipoic Acid daily, combined with 1000 mg Acetyl-L-Carnitine, 50 mg Resveratrol, and 800 UI Cholecalciferol.
study_duration: 30 days of intervention, with follow-up at 60 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) on prostate cancer cell growth, migration, and invasion, focusing on autophagy inhibition and oxidative/redox balance disruption.
results_summary: ALA reduced cell growth, motility, and colony formation in prostate cancer cells (LNCaP and DU-145) by inhibiting autophagy and disrupting the KEAP1/Nrf2/p62 signaling pathway. It also downregulated TGFβ1, vimentin, and fibronectin expression, suggesting anti-metastatic potential.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cell lines (LNCaP and DU-145) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether repeated treatment with Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) modulates neuroinflammation and reduces pain in a mouse model of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome type I (CRPS-I).
results_summary: Repeated ALA treatment reduced mechanical and cold allodynia, restored nest-building capacity, and decreased oxidative stress and neuroinflammation markers in the spinal cord and sciatic nerve without affecting locomotion or body weight.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice with induced Chronic Post-Ischemia Pain Injury (CPIP), a model of CRPS-I.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) treatment during in vitro maturation (IVM) improves porcine somatic cell nuclear transfer (SCNT) embryo production by reducing oxidative stress.
results_summary: ALA at 12.5 μM significantly improved blastocyst formation rates in both parthenogenetic and SCNT embryos, reduced reactive oxygen species, increased glutathione levels, and decreased apoptosis in cumulus cells and blastocysts. Higher doses (25-50 μM) did not show the same benefits.
population_specificity: Porcine oocytes and embryos in an in vitro setting.
study_duration: Duration of IVM period (exact length not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) and punicic acid (PUA) on inflammatory and metabolism-related gene expression under oxidative stress in muscle cells.
results_summary: The study found that ALA (50 µM) combined with PUA (80 µM) reduced inflammation-related gene expression and increased metabolism-related gene expression (Pparγ, Pgc-1α) in muscle cells under oxidative stress. H2O2 unexpectedly increased Fndc5 expression, but the combination of PUA and ALA maximally upregulated metabolic genes.
population_specificity: Muscle cells (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 5, 25, 50, 100, and 200 µM of ALA (optimal concentration: 50 µM)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) in improving functional and symptomatic outcomes in patients with diabetes mellitus type I and type II.
results_summary: The study found that ALA did not show statistically significant improvements in pain reduction or functional scales compared to placebo, with no specific dosages identified as effective for neuropathic pain relief.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes mellitus type I and type II experiencing neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether alpha-lipoic acid, as an adjuvant to olfactory training, improves smell loss in post-COVID-19 patients compared to olfactory training alone.
results_summary: Both groups (alpha-lipoic acid + olfactory training and placebo + olfactory training) showed significant improvement in olfactory function, but no statistically significant differences were found between the two groups, suggesting alpha-lipoic acid did not enhance outcomes beyond olfactory training alone.
population_specificity: Adult outpatients with persistent smell loss for more than 3 months after COVID-19 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential therapeutic effects of α-lipoic acid (α-LA) on inflammation during the development and progression of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD).
results_summary: α-LA supplementation attenuated pro-inflammatory n-6 PUFA pathway activity, increased anti-inflammatory n-3 PUFA pathway activity, reduced arachidonic acid concentration, and modulated cytokine levels, suggesting protective effects against inflammation in MASLD.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high-fat diet (HFD) for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effect of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (LA) on dextran sulfate sodium salt-induced ulcerative colitis (UC) and its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: LA significantly alleviated UC symptoms and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines in mice. It also inhibited intestinal cell apoptosis, oxidative stress, and ferroptosis by regulating the Keap1-Nrf2 signaling pathway and attenuating endoplasmic reticulum stress.
population_specificity: Dextran sulfate sodium salt-induced UC mice and an in vitro erastin-induced ferroptosis model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive effect of alpha-lipoic acid on memory impairment and oxidative stress in rats exposed to methamphetamine.
results_summary: Alpha-lipoic acid reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA), increased antioxidant enzyme activity (SOD and catalase), and prevented memory impairment and anxiety-like behavior in methamphetamine-exposed rats. The findings suggest a protective role against methamphetamine-induced hippocampal damage.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (200-220 g)
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg and 40 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally at 30 min, 24 h, and 48 h post-methamphetamine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) could inhibit epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and reduce migration in ovarian cancer cells.
results_summary: ALA inhibited EMT markers and reduced proliferation, invasion, and migration in ovarian cancer cells, particularly when combined with TGF β1. The results suggest ALA may suppress ovarian cancer metastasis by regulating EMT.
population_specificity: SKOV-3 ovarian adenocarcinoma cell line (epithelial subtype).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) with trelagliptin and remogliflozin improves cardiac biomarkers in diabetic cardiomyopathy (DCM) by targeting oxidative stress, inflammation, and glucotoxicity.
results_summary: The study found that ALA supplementation enhanced the effects of trelagliptin and remogliflozin, significantly reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and myopathy biomarkers in diabetic rats. Immunohistochemical analysis supported these findings, showing reduced cathepsin B activity in heart cells.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic male rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic potential and mechanisms of action of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) in patients with low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSILs), focusing on its effects on antioxidant and lipid status parameters.
results_summary: ALA supplementation did not significantly affect oxidative status biomarkers but increased serum superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity in patients with higher dietary antioxidant intake. It also resulted in a small but statistically significant increase in serum LDL, influenced by participants' initial lipid status.
population_specificity: 100 patients with low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSILs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) could mitigate fluoride-induced liver injury by improving mitochondrial biogenesis, dynamics, and inhibiting the Wnt/Ca2+ pathway.
results_summary: ALA reduced fluoride-induced liver damage by enhancing antioxidant capacity, improving mitochondrial function, and inhibiting the Wnt/Ca2+ pathway, though it did not reduce fluoride accumulation in bones.
population_specificity: Mice with fluoride-induced liver injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (LA) could mitigate the toxic effects of copper overload in cells with inactivated Cu transporter Atp7a and explore its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: LA improved cellular morphology and mitochondrial function in Atp7a-/- cells, similar to the Cu chelator BCS, but through distinct mechanisms. LA increased selenium levels and upregulated selenoproteins, improving redox balance and reversing protein oxidation caused by elevated Cu.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 preadipocytes (a mouse cell line) and tissues from a Wilson disease animal model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of oral and combined oral + intravenous Alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) treatment on pain and physical examination findings in patients with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: Patients treated with intravenous followed by oral ALA showed significantly lower pain (VAS), symptom severity (BSSS), and functional impairment (BFDS) scores at 1 and 3 months compared to oral-only or no-medication groups. The study concluded that iv. ALA is effective for CTS symptom relief.
population_specificity: 115 patients diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) in combination with other nutrients could reduce adverse pregnancy outcomes such as preterm birth, pelvic pain, contractions, and hospitalization.
results_summary: The study found that ALA, combined with HMWHA, magnesium, vitamin B6, and vitamin D, significantly reduced adverse pregnancy outcomes, including preterm birth, pelvic pain, contractions, miscarriages, and hospitalizations compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Pregnant women starting supplementation from the 7th gestational week until delivery.
effective_dosage: 100 mg ALA daily, combined with other nutrients.
study_duration: From the 7th gestational week until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential therapeutic targets and molecular mechanisms of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) in treating primary ovarian insufficiency (POI).
results_summary: The study identified 152 potential therapeutic targets for ALA in POI, with key pathways including cAMP, PI3K/AKT, estrogen, and apoptosis signaling. Molecular docking confirmed ALA's binding to top hub targets like STAT3, CASP3, and ESR1, suggesting multi-target and multi-pathway mechanisms.
population_specificity: Women with primary ovarian insufficiency (POI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) monotherapy, pregabalin monotherapy, and their combination in treating neuropathic pain due to peripheral neuropathies.
results_summary: The study found that pregabalin was superior to ALA in reducing pain intensity, but combining ALA with pregabalin did not provide additional benefits. ALA showed modest improvements in quality of life compared to baseline but was less effective than pregabalin.
population_specificity: 55 participants with peripheral neuropathies (20 with diabetic neuropathy, 19 with small fiber neuropathy, and 16 with other neuropathies).
effective_dosage: Maximal tolerated doses (MTD) were used, but specific amounts are not provided.
study_duration: Each treatment (ALA, pregabalin, and combination) was administered for 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (α-LA) could protect against alcohol-induced cardiac damage by mitigating oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and PINK1/Parkin-mediated mitophagy.
results_summary: α-LA reduced mortality, serum aldehyde levels, and cardiac dysfunction (e.g., enlarged left ventricles, reduced ejection fraction) in mice exposed to chronic alcohol. It also mitigated oxidative stress, collagen accumulation, and mitochondrial dysfunction by activating aldehyde dehydrogenase 2 and inhibiting PINK1/Parkin-related mitophagy.
population_specificity: Mice fed a 4.8% (v/v) alcohol diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of oral-administered Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) versus a placebo in patients with diabetic sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy (DSPN) and determine the optimal dosage for this treatment.
results_summary: ALA treatment improved total symptoms' score (TSS) and global satisfaction in a dose-dependent manner but did not show favorable results for VAS, VPT, NIS-LL, or NCS outcomes. The study found ALA effective in reducing sensory symptoms in DSPN patients.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy (DSPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of add-on Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) as a prophylactic agent for adolescent migraine when combined with flunarizine.
results_summary: The study found that add-on ALA significantly reduced migraine frequency, severity, and disability scores, increased serum thiol levels, and decreased serum CGRP levels compared to flunarizine alone. The responder rate was significantly higher in the ALA group (80%) than in the control group (33.3%).
population_specificity: Adolescents with migraine (60 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of alpha-lipoic acid, pioglitazone, and their combination on PCOS-related outcomes, including hormonal profiles, oxidative stress, and lipid metabolism.
results_summary: Alpha-lipoic acid alone improved body weight, BMI, and FSH levels but was less effective than pioglitazone in improving oxidative stress, BMI, and menstrual cyclicity. The combination therapy showed superior effects compared to monotherapy for most measured outcomes.
population_specificity: 120 patients with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) combined with ischemic postconditioning (Post) could reduce myocardial infarction and cell death in diabetic rats following ischemia/reperfusion injury.
results_summary: ALA alone showed positive effects on lactate dehydrogenase and infarct size, while the combination of ALA and Post significantly reduced apoptotic markers (Bax, Bax/Bcl2, cleaved caspase-3) and improved histopathological outcomes compared to single treatments. The combined therapy effectively inhibited apoptosis and promoted cardiac recovery in diabetic conditions.
population_specificity: Rats with chronic type-II diabetes induced by high-fat diet and streptozotocin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining nutraceutical supplements (including Alpha-Lipoic Acid) with oxygen-ozone therapy and pharmacological therapy could reduce disability and improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute radicular low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that combining nutraceutical supplements and oxygen-ozone therapy with pharmacological therapy significantly improved disability scores (ODI), pain scores (NRS-11), and physical health outcomes compared to pharmacological therapy alone. The combination also reduced the percentage of patients requiring adjuvant opioid therapy.
population_specificity: 62 patients with acute radicular low back pain secondary to disc herniation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antimetastatic effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) and auraptene (AUR) combination on U87 human glioblastoma cells.
results_summary: The study found that the ALA-AUR combination reduced cell migration and metastasis in U87 cells by decreasing MMP-2 and MMP-9 expression at both mRNA and protein levels, as well as their enzymatic activity.
population_specificity: U87 human glioblastoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and limitations of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) as a therapeutic strategy for PCOS, particularly in combination with inositols, to improve insulin resistance, reduce androgen levels, and enhance reproductive outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that ALA, especially when combined with inositols (MYO), significantly improves insulin resistance in PCOS patients, particularly in obese/overweight individuals with a family history of type 2 diabetes. Additionally, ALA treatment, particularly in combination with MYO, showed beneficial effects on endocrine patterns, menstrual regularity, and ovulation rhythm.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), especially obese/overweight patients with a family history of type 2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Alpha-Lipoic Acid as a pharmacological intervention for improving sperm concentration, morphology, and motility in male infertility.
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lipoic Acid, among other pharmacological interventions, showed significant improvements in sperm concentration, morphology, and motility. However, the overall evidence quality was rated as moderate to very low due to limited patient numbers.
population_specificity: Men with infertility issues

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) on psychopathological scores, neurotrophic factors, and oxidative stress in patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS).
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly improved negative symptoms (SANS score) but not positive symptoms (SAPS score). It did not significantly affect oxidative stress markers (MDA, GSH) or BDNF levels compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 20 patients with treatment-resistant schizophrenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of dietary supplements, including Alpha-Lipoic Acid, in the management of glaucoma.
results_summary: The study found limited evidence for the benefit of Alpha-Lipoic Acid in glaucoma treatment, with no strong clinical outcomes demonstrated.
population_specificity: Glaucoma patients (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) in treating diabetes mellitus by examining its antioxidant properties and metabolic effects.
results_summary: The study found that ALA improved glucose metabolism, reduced oxidative stress, enhanced endothelial function, decreased platelet reactivity, and showed moderate weight loss benefits, though results on insulin metabolism were inconsistent. ALA also inhibited NFkB, chelated metal ions, and induced AMPK expression.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes mellitus (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) supplementation in improving sperm motility and vitality in primary infertile males with idiopathic asthenozoospermia.
results_summary: Daily supplementation with 600 mg ALA significantly improved total sperm motility, progressive motility, and sperm vitality compared to the placebo group after 90 days.
population_specificity: Primary infertile males with idiopathic asthenozoospermia (n=80).
effective_dosage: 600 mg daily (divided into two 300 mg doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) food supplements in reducing idiopathic pain in normoglycemic adults.
results_summary: ALA significantly reduced pain scores (NRS and VAS) compared to placebo, with no reported adverse effects, decreased glycemia, or toxicity. No significant differences were found among pain source subgroups.
population_specificity: 210 normoglycemic adults with idiopathic pain (neuropathic pain, arthralgia, or myalgia).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the safety and potential adverse effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid supplementation in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study identified high-grade proteinuria as an unexpected adverse event in the treatment arm, with four biopsy-proven cases of NELL1-associated membranous nephropathy and a fifth suspected case linked to Alpha-Lipoic Acid. Discontinuation of the supplement and supportive therapy led to remission.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation improves biological indices (e.g., albumin, creatinine) indicative of diabetic nephropathy (DN) in humans.
results_summary: The study found that ALA supplementation reduced 24-hour urine albumin excretion in diabetic patients but concluded that it did not improve biological indices reflecting DN overall, with limited evidence warranting cautious interpretation.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes (specifically those with or at risk of diabetic nephropathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize and discuss the neuroprotective effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (α-LA) on cognition and its molecular mechanisms, to understand its therapeutic potential in neurodegenerative disorders.
results_summary: Preclinical studies indicate α-LA improves memory in animal models of aging and Alzheimer's disease, with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective effects. However, few human studies have been conducted to confirm these benefits.
population_specificity: Animal models of memory loss associated with aging and Alzheimer's disease; limited human data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) on oxidative stress, inflammation, and mood conditions in women with episodic migraine.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly reduced serum levels of MDA and CRP, as well as improved depression, anxiety, and stress scores, but did not show statistically significant changes in GSH, TAC, TOS, or OSI.
population_specificity: Women with episodic migraine (n=79 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of single and short-term chronic ALA supplementation on muscle strength recovery and performance in athletes after intensive exercise.
results_summary: ALA supplementation moderately inhibited muscle damage and inflammation, preserved back squat performance compared to placebo, but showed no antioxidative effects.
population_specificity: 17 male resistance and endurance-experienced athletes.
study_duration: Short-term chronic supplementation (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of four different dosages of alpha-lipoic acid on glycemic status and lipid profile in subjects with euglycemia or dysglycemia.
results_summary: Higher dosages (800 and 1200 mg/day) significantly improved glycemic status and lipid profile compared to baseline and lower dosages, with 1200 mg/day showing the most pronounced effects. Adverse events were reported but did not differ significantly among dosage groups.
population_specificity: 322 patients with euglycemia or dysglycemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation improves sperm motility and reduces lipid peroxidation and DNA fragmentation in men post-varicocelectomy.
results_summary: ALA significantly improved total and progressive sperm motility compared to placebo. Both ALA and placebo groups showed reduced sperm lipid peroxidation and DNA damage, though the study did not compare these reductions between groups.
population_specificity: Men who underwent microsurgical varicocele repair.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) supplementation on glycemic markers such as glucose and hemoglobin A1c.
results_summary: The study found that ALA supplementation had a significant impact on improving glycemic markers, suggesting potential benefits for glucose metabolism. The dose-response meta-analysis indicated varying efficacy based on dosage levels.
population_specificity: Patients from clinical trials included in the meta-analysis (specific population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Alpha-Lipoic Acid supplementation reduces elevated plasma triglycerides in overweight or obese adults and whether it promotes weight loss, improves oxidative stress, and reduces inflammation.
results_summary: R-LA did not reduce triglyceride levels but led to greater BMI reduction, weight loss, and body fat loss, particularly in women and obese participants. It also increased antioxidant gene expression and reduced markers of inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese adults (BMI ≥ 25) aged 21-60 with elevated plasma triglycerides (≥100 mg/dL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation on serum levels of leptin and adiponectin in the context of obesity-related dysregulation.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that ALA significantly decreased serum leptin levels and increased adiponectin levels, particularly in studies lasting more than 8 weeks. However, the authors noted the need for further research on dosage, duration, and gender-specific effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity-related dysregulation of adipocytokines (specific demographics not detailed).
study_duration: Varied, with notable effects in studies lasting more than 8 weeks.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify the study's goal regarding Alpha-Lipoic Acid.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Alpha-Lipoic Acid.
population_specificity: Not specified in the provided abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) supplementation on obesity measurements, including weight, BMI, waist circumference, and fat mass, through a systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly reduced weight and BMI in a two-class meta-analysis, with no evidence of departure from linearity in terms of dose or duration. The effect on waist circumference was dependent on study duration, but further trials are needed to assess central obesity measurements more reliably.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with obesity measurements assessed in included studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dose-response analysis performed but exact dosages not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: Not specified (duration-response analysis performed but exact lengths not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of α-lipoic acid supplementation on glycemic control and lipid profile in pre-diabetic, overweight/obese adults.
results_summary: The study investigated α-lipoic acid's impact on glycemic control and lipid profile but did not report specific results in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pre-diabetic, overweight/obese adults with dyslipidemia (n=12).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a supplement containing Alpha-Lipoic Acid (among other ingredients) on cognitive function in older adults with subjective cognitive impairment (SCI).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Alpha-Lipoic Acid's effects, as the study is proposed and outcomes are anticipated but not yet reported.
population_specificity: Older adults with subjective cognitive impairment (SCI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of a multi-ingredient supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of α-lipoic acid supplementation in improving dyslipidemia, focusing on serum lipid endpoints such as TC, LDL-C, HDL-C, and TG.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent effects of α-lipoic acid on blood lipids, with wide variations in responses for total cholesterol, LDL-C, HDL-C, and triglycerides, suggesting little consistent benefit. Further well-controlled studies are needed to confirm potential benefits in hypercholesterolemic individuals.
population_specificity: Adults supplemented with oral α-lipoic acid versus a placebo or control.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA), mefenamic acid, and their combination compared with placebo on girls with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The study compared ALA, mefenamic acid, and their combination against placebo in reducing dysmenorrhea symptoms, but specific results for ALA alone are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Female students with moderate to severe dysmenorrhea living in dormitories of Qazvin University of Medical Sciences.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a three-month treatment with Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) improves endothelial function, assessed by flow-mediated dilation (FMD), and clinical/metabolic risk factors in overweight/obese youths.
results_summary: The study investigated ALA's effects on endothelial function and metabolic risk factors in overweight/obese youths compared to healthy controls, but the abstract does not provide specific outcome results.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese children (n=67) and normal-weight metabolically healthy controls (n=22).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically summarize clinical trials examining the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid supplementation on the lipid profile of adults.
results_summary: The study found that Alpha-Lipoic Acid's effects on lipid profile remain controversial, with mixed results across clinical trials. A meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate these effects, but no definitive conclusion was reached.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the clinical use of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) for psychiatric and neurological conditions and identify gaps in evidence for its therapeutic application.
results_summary: ALA showed promise in improving schizophrenia symptoms and antipsychotic side effects, preventing Alzheimer's disease progression, and reversing clinical and oxidative imbalances in stroke patients. Results for other neurological conditions were preliminary, highlighting the need for more robust clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients with psychiatric (e.g., schizophrenia) and neurological disorders (e.g., Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, stroke, encephalopathy, multiple sclerosis, traumatic brain injury, mitochondrial disorders, migraine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation on glycemic control and lipid profiles in patients with metabolic diseases.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly improved fasting glucose, insulin levels, insulin resistance, hemoglobin A1c, triglycerides, total cholesterol, and LDL-cholesterol, but had no effect on HDL-cholesterol.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) supplementation could reduce oxidative stress, improve insulin resistance, and influence clinical outcomes in critically ill ICU patients.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly increased total antioxidant capacity (TAC), reduced glucose levels, and hindered an increase in insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) compared to placebo. However, no significant differences were observed in other biochemical markers or clinical outcomes between the groups.
population_specificity: Critically ill ICU patients expected to stay at least seven days and requiring enteral feeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid supplementation on maternal circulating values of adiponectin, leptin, and related ratios in pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: The study found that 100 mg of ALA daily for 8 weeks increased adiponectin, A/L, and A/H ratios while decreasing L/A and MDA/TAC ratios in women with GDM. Maternal fasting serum glucose and HOMA-IR levels also significantly decreased.
population_specificity: Pregnant women diagnosed with GDM between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of alpha-lipoic acid supplementation on C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in clinical trial studies.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that alpha-lipoic acid supplementation significantly reduced CRP levels, particularly in patients with baseline CRP >3 mg/l, non-diabetic patients, and trials lasting >8 weeks. The effect size was moderate but statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with elevated CRP levels, including non-diabetic individuals.
study_duration: Varied, with significant effects observed in trials >8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of continuous oral administration of alpha-lipoic acid (600 mg daily) in pregnant women over at least 7 weeks of gestation.
results_summary: The study found no adverse effects in mothers or newborns, with outcomes comparable to or better than the control group. Alpha-lipoic acid was deemed safe for use during pregnancy.
population_specificity: 610 pregnant women treated with alpha-lipoic acid during gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) supplementation on anthropometric indices (e.g., body weight, BMI) in adult subjects through a meta-analysis of placebo-controlled clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found that ALA supplementation slightly but significantly reduced body weight and BMI. However, the effect size was modest, and the authors noted that ALA may not be cost-effective for weight loss.
population_specificity: Adult subjects (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) on weight and body mass index (BMI) through a meta-analysis of randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled studies.
results_summary: ALA treatment resulted in a statistically significant but modest mean weight loss of 1.27 kg and a BMI reduction of -0.43 kg/m² compared to placebo. The effects were small, and further research is needed to assess long-term benefits and optimal dosing.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of multiple randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) on plasma adiponectin levels and metabolic risk factors in patients with schizophrenia.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly increased plasma adiponectin concentrations and reduced fasting glucose and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) activity. The study suggests ALA may improve metabolic risk factors in schizophrenia patients.
population_specificity: Eighteen schizophrenic patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a food supplement containing α-lipoic acid on glyco-metabolic control and oxidative stress markers in type 2 diabetics.
results_summary: The study compared the effects of a supplement containing 600 mg of α-lipoic acid to a placebo, but the abstract does not provide specific results regarding efficacy or outcomes.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetics (n=105)
effective_dosage: 600 mg of α-lipoic acid (frequency not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation could reduce atrial fibrillation (AF) recurrence and inflammation markers after catheter ablation in patients with paroxysmal AF.
results_summary: ALA significantly reduced serum markers of inflammation but did not prevent AF recurrence after ablation. Age was the only independent prognostic risk factor for AF recurrence.
population_specificity: Patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation who underwent catheter ablation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if postoperative Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) administration improves outcomes, such as nerve conduction velocity and pillar pain incidence, after median nerve decompression surgery for carpal tunnel syndrome.
results_summary: ALA did not significantly improve nerve conduction velocity or Boston Carpal Tunnel score but reduced the incidence of postoperative pillar pain. Static 2-point discrimination improved in both groups.
population_specificity: 64 patients with proven carpal tunnel syndrome undergoing median nerve decompression surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the anticancer potential of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (LA) and its derivatives, focusing on their mitochondria-targeted mechanisms and cytotoxic effects in cancer cells.
results_summary: LA triggers mitochondrial apoptosis in cancer cells while sparing non-transformed cells, impairs oncogenic signaling, and exhibits anti-metastatic potential. Pre-clinical studies support its antitumor activity, and clinical trials are underway for its analog CPI-613.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro and in vivo) and non-transformed primary cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if oral supplementation of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) enhances the effectiveness of standard progesterone treatment in resolving subchorionic hematomas in women with threatened miscarriage.
results_summary: The study found that ALA supplementation, combined with progesterone, significantly accelerated the resorption of subchorionic hematomas compared to progesterone alone. While symptoms improved faster in the ALA group, the difference in symptom resolution was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in the first trimester with threatened miscarriage and ultrasound-confirmed subchorionic hematoma.
effective_dosage: 600 mg ALA daily (300 mg twice daily) and 400 mg progesterone daily (200 mg twice daily).
study_duration: Until complete resolution of clinical symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an antioxidant diet supplemented with alpha-lipoic acid could improve endothelial dysfunction in adolescents with type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that an antioxidant diet significantly improved endothelial dysfunction when supplemented with alpha-lipoic acid, unlike diet with placebo or controls. A significant reduction in bolus insulin was also observed.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents (ages 17 ± 3.9 yrs) with type 1 diabetes (duration 9.5 ± 5.3 yrs) using intensified insulin therapy.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) supplementation on semen parameters and oxidative stress biomarkers in infertile men.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly improved total sperm count, concentration, motility, and oxidative stress markers (TAC and malondialdehyde) compared to placebo, but did not affect ejaculate volume, normal morphology, or live sperm percentage.
population_specificity: Infertile men attending an infertility clinic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) on serum biomarkers of joint damage and inflammation in women with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in serum inflammatory biomarkers (hs-CRP, TNF-α, IL-6, MMP-3) between the ALA and placebo groups after 8 weeks of supplementation. Dietary intake, physical activity, and anxiety levels also remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Women with rheumatoid arthritis, aged 20-50 years (n = 65 completed the trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of alpha-lipoic acid supplementation on oxidative stress markers in patients with schizophrenia compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: LA supplementation reduced lipid peroxidation and oxidative protein damage and improved antioxidant capacity in healthy controls, but no significant changes were observed in schizophrenic patients. SOD activity decreased in patients and fluctuated in controls over the study period.
population_specificity: 18 medicated patients with schizophrenia and 38 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the efficacy and safety of alpha-lipoic acid supplementation in treating neuropathic pain, particularly during pregnancy.
results_summary: Alpha-lipoic acid demonstrated antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity, significantly improving pain and paraesthesia in patients with sciatica, carpal tunnel syndrome, and diabetic neuropathy. The study concluded that it has a high safety profile and is a promising candidate for managing neuropathic pain during pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with neuropathic pain conditions (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome, sciatica, meralgia paraesthetica).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oral alpha-lipoic acid supplementation on contrast sensitivity in patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Alpha-lipoic acid stabilized contrast sensitivity in type 1 diabetes patients and improved it in type 2 diabetes patients, while contrast sensitivity declined in untreated diabetic patients. A slight improvement was also noted in the control group at one spatial frequency.
population_specificity: 12 patients with type 1 diabetes (43±12 years), 48 patients with type 2 diabetes (59±10 years), and 20 control subjects (33±8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) on oxidative stress parameters and its potential as an adjunct therapy for diabetic retinopathy (DR).
results_summary: ALA was found to prevent vascular damage, preserve retinal capillary pericytes, improve insulin sensitivity in type-2 diabetes, and suppress expression of VEGF, angiopoietin 2, and erythropoietin by blocking superoxide formation. The study suggests ALA supplementation could help prevent vision loss in diabetic patients.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic retinopathy and type-2 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 14 days of α-lipoic acid supplementation could reduce exercise-induced oxidative stress, specifically DNA damage, in healthy males.
results_summary: The study found that α-lipoic acid supplementation increased blood antioxidant capacity and selectively protected against DNA damage and lipid peroxidation after exercise, though it did not prevent mitochondrial DNA damage or protein oxidation.
population_specificity: 12 healthy male participants (age 28 ± 10 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid supplementation could improve blood redox status in individuals with G6PD deficiency compared to controls.
results_summary: LA supplementation significantly increased GSH, catalase, and TAC levels while reducing TBARS and PC in both groups. It also increased uric acid levels in the G6PD-deficient group, but bilirubin and hemoglobin levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Eight adults with G6PD deficiency and eight controls with normal G6PD levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (LA) in modulating oxidative stress and its potential benefits in metabolic diseases like diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that LA, in both oxidized and reduced forms, exhibits antioxidant properties by quenching reactive oxygen species (ROS) and chelating transition metals. Dietary supplementation with LA showed promise in improving redox imbalance in diabetes and cardiovascular disease models.
population_specificity: In vivo models of disease (not specified if human or animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Alpha-Lipoic Acid supplementation on inflammation, oxidative stress, and serum lipid profiles in hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: ALA supplementation significantly reduced hsCRP levels (a cardiovascular risk factor) and increased HDL-C concentrations, though other lipid parameters and oxidative stress markers showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: 63 hemodialysis patients with end-stage renal disease (age range: 22-79 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of oral DL-alpha-lipoic acid (ALA) supplementation on glycemic control and oxidative stress in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM).
results_summary: ALA supplementation showed a dose-dependent trend in reducing fasting blood glucose and HbA1c, and suppressed lipid peroxidation (measured by urinary PGF2α-Isoprostanes) compared to placebo. However, no significant effects were observed on 8-OHdG levels, urinary microalbumin, or serum creatinine.
population_specificity: 38 outpatients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Alpha-Lipoic Acid (ALA) could protect against lipid-induced insulin resistance and improve insulin sensitivity and secretion in overweight and obese humans.
results_summary: The study found that ALA did not significantly improve insulin secretion rates or protect against lipid-induced insulin resistance in overweight and obese subjects. Lipid infusion impaired insulin sensitivity regardless of ALA pretreatment.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese male subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether α-lipoic acid supplementation, alone or combined with exercise, improves clinical outcomes in obese individuals with impaired glucose tolerance.
results_summary: The study found that α-lipoic acid alone increased LDL oxidation, potentially worsening cardiovascular risk, but this effect was abolished when combined with exercise. Exercise plus α-lipoic acid improved antioxidant capacity and reduced body fat, though no significant effects were seen on glycemic regulation.
population_specificity: Obese individuals (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) with impaired glucose tolerance (n=24).
effective_dosage: 1 gram per day of α-lipoic acid.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention (after a 12-week control phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of Alpha-Lipoic Acid (LA) in skin protection from photodamage and ageing, focusing on its antioxidant properties and cellular functions.
results_summary: The study found that LA has strong antioxidant properties and effectively mitigates skin ageing caused by oxidative stress and UV exposure, making it a powerful anti-ageing agent when used appropriately.
population_specificity: General discussion on skin ageing, no specific population mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the amino acid score, true digestibility, and biological value of a protein module derived from amaranth and chicken egg protein.
results_summary: The amaranth protein concentrate had high protein content (70.4%) and the protein module showed no significant differences in digestibility (99.0%) compared to egg protein, indicating high biological value and no amino acid limitations.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (n=32, divided into two groups).
effective_dosage: Protein module composed of 58% amaranth protein concentrate and 42% chicken egg protein.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily oral antioxidant supplementation, including Alpha-Lipoic Acid, was safe, tolerable, and effective for improving or stabilizing cognitive decline in individuals with Down syndrome and dementia.
results_summary: The study found that antioxidant supplementation, including Alpha-Lipoic Acid, was safe and well-tolerated but did not improve cognitive functioning or stabilize cognitive decline in individuals with Down syndrome and dementia. Plasma levels of alpha-tocopherol increased in the treatment group, indicating good compliance, but no cognitive benefits were observed.
population_specificity: Individuals with Down syndrome over age 40 years who had dementia of the Alzheimer type.
effective_dosage: 600 mg of Alpha-Lipoic Acid daily, combined with 900 IU of alpha-tocopherol and 200 mg of ascorbic acid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of decolorized pectic polysaccharides from Amaranth caudatus leaves on hippocampal GLP-1 levels and gut microbiota in rats.
results_summary: The study found that D-ACLP significantly increased hippocampal GLP-1 levels, elevated butyric acid and total short-chain fatty acids in the cecum, and enhanced gut microbiota diversity, particularly boosting Actinobacteriota and unclassified Oscillospiraceae.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photocatalytic degradation efficiency of anionic amaranth (AM) dye using hybrid composite photocatalysts (SnP/AA@ZnO and SnP@ZnO) under visible light irradiation.
results_summary: SnP/AA@ZnO demonstrated significantly enhanced photocatalytic activity, degrading 95% of AM dye within 60 minutes at a rate constant of 0.048 min-1, outperforming SnP, ZnO, and SnP@ZnO. The improved performance was attributed to the synergistic effect between SnP and ZnO facilitated by adipic acid anchors.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on dye degradation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study how activated sludge (AS) organisms respond to the xenobiotic effects of amaranth, focusing on changes in trophic levels and microbial community dynamics.
results_summary: The study found that amaranth significantly altered the dominant trophic units in AS, promoting bacterial segments (e.g., Pseudomonas and azo-degrading bacteria) and shifting fauna organisms from ciliates and amoebas to flagellates. These changes facilitated amaranth biodetoxification but also led to a decline in AS quality.
population_specificity: Activated sludge microbial communities in wastewater treatment plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of two systemic seed treatments (Apron Star and Menceron) in managing Myzus persicae infestations and their impact on fresh leaf yield in two Amaranthus species.
results_summary: Seed treatments significantly reduced live aphid counts and leaf damage compared to untreated controls, with Menceron providing better protection than Apron Star. No significant differences were observed between storage periods (24 h vs. 3 months).
population_specificity: Amaranthus blitum (2 selections) and Amaranthus hybridus (4 selections) in East Africa.
effective_dosage: Apron Star (thiamethoxam 20 g/kg + metalaxyl-M 20 g/kg + difenoconazole 2 g/kg); Menceron (imidacloprid 233 g/L + pencycuron 50 g/L + thiram 107 g/L).
study_duration: Evaluated at 6, 8, and 10 days after infestation (DAI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic mechanisms behind S-metolachlor resistance in a Palmer amaranth biotype, focusing on the roles of cytochrome P450 and glutathione S-transferase inhibitors.
results_summary: The resistant Palmer amaranth biotype showed greater inhibition of root elongation when treated with a mixture of NBD-Cl and S-metolachlor compared to S-metolachlor alone. The resistant biotype also produced significantly more S-metolachlor metabolites and exhibited less reduction in cerotic acid production than the susceptible standard.
population_specificity: Palmer amaranth (Amaranthus palmeri S. Wats.) biotype resistant to S-metolachlor from Arkansas, USA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a UV/ZVI/H2O2 process in decomposing two organic dyes, AM E123 and AM ACID, and assess the stability and reusability of the catalyst.
results_summary: The process achieved 85.5% and 80.85% removal efficiency for AM E123 and AM ACID, respectively, with complete decolorization. The catalyst demonstrated high stability and reusability over three cycles, with minimal efficiency loss.
population_specificity: Not applicable (environmental study on dye decomposition).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (catalyst amount not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of UV-C light treatments on the biocompound content of amaranth sprouts compared to chlorine treatments.
results_summary: UV-C treatment (3 cm, 15 min) increased the content of p-coumaroylquinic acid (17.7%) in amaranth sprouts, outperforming chlorine treatments in enhancing phenolic and flavonoid levels. The optimal treatment for bioactive compound concentration was UV-C at 3 cm for 15 min, with no significant impact on color parameters.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or plant-based study).
effective_dosage: UV-C at 3 cm for 15 min; chlorine at 100 and 200 ppm for 15 min.
study_duration: Single treatment session (duration not specified beyond exposure times).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a bio nanocomposite (CuO NRs immobilized in Alg-Agar biopolymer) as a photocatalyst for degrading amaranth (AN) dye in water under visible light.
results_summary: The bio nanocomposite achieved 95.69% degradation of amaranth dye under optimized conditions (45 min irradiation, 80 ppm AN concentration, 20 mg catalyst dose, pH 4). The degradation followed pseudo-first-order kinetics, with photogenerated •O2- radicals mineralizing the dye into non-toxic byproducts like CO2 and H2O.
population_specificity: Aquatic environment (water contaminated with amaranth dye).
effective_dosage: Catalyst dose of 20 mg per treatment.
study_duration: 45 minutes of irradiation per treatment cycle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the phytotoxic effects of microplastics (polystyrene, polyethylene, and polypropylene) on amaranth seed germination and root growth.
results_summary: Microplastics inhibited shoot extension and root growth in amaranth, with polypropylene causing the most significant damage. High concentrations of microplastics led to oxidative damage and disorganized root cells due to reactive oxygen species accumulation.
population_specificity: Amaranth (Amaranthus mangostanus L.) seeds and seedlings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a PFC-PEF hybrid system in degrading the azo dye Amaranth and generating electricity.
results_summary: The PFC-PEF system achieved high decolorization efficiency (PFC: 98.85%; PEF: 95.69%) under complete circuit connection, with UV light irradiation playing a pivotal role in dye degradation and reactive species formation. The study also highlighted the system's ability to generate and regenerate Fe2+ and produce hydrogen peroxide.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on dye degradation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of hydrothermal treatment on the morphological, water-binding, and rheological-functional properties of puffed and raw Amaranthus caudatus flour suspensions.
results_summary: Hydrothermal treatment at 80°C for 1 h significantly increased water absorption and viscosity in puffed and raw flour suspensions, with puffed suspensions showing higher values. Raw flour suspensions exhibited increasing color differences with temperature, while blends with puffed flour showed reduced color change and increased water absorption with higher puffed flour content.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on flour suspensions)
effective_dosage: Not specified (suspensions treated at varying temperatures and durations)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of liposomes loaded with soybean lunasin and amaranth unsaponifiable matter (UM + LunLip) in preventing melanoma skin cancer in an allograft mice model.
results_summary: UM + LunLip treatments significantly inhibited tumor growth (68% topically, up to 99% subcutaneously), reduced cell proliferation markers, and activated apoptosis. Larger tumors showed increased necrotic areas.
population_specificity: Allograft mice model with induced melanoma B16-F10 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antioxidant and anti-inflammatory capacity of liposomes loaded with amaranth unsaponifiable matter and soybean lunasin in an in vitro model using fibroblasts and macrophages.
results_summary: UM + LunLip significantly decreased ROS production by 77% in fibroblasts. UMLip was most effective in reducing tumor necrosis factor-α (71-90%) and interleukin-6 (43-55%), with liposomes containing unsaponifiable matter outperforming empty or lunasin-only liposomes.
population_specificity: Fibroblasts (CHON-002) and macrophages (RAW 264.7 and peritoneal macrophages) in an in vitro model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of blue LED460nm light irradiation on microbial inhibition, antioxidant activity, and shelf-life extension in freshly cut amaranth.
results_summary: Blue LED460nm light improved antioxidant enzyme activity, extended shelf life by 2-3 days, and effectively inhibited microbial growth, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The optimal irradiation intensity was 30 μmol/(m2·s).
population_specificity: Freshly cut amaranth samples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of micro and nano bubble (MNB) water treated with CO2 or air on the germination rate and growth of Amaranth green (Amaranthus viridis).
results_summary: MNB water with CO2 significantly improved Amaranth germination (90%) and plant growth compared to MNB water with air or tap water. Longer treatment durations (10-15 minutes) further enhanced stem height and root size.
population_specificity: Amaranth green (Amaranthus viridis) plants.
effective_dosage: Water treatments varied by duration: 5, 10, or 15 minutes for MNB + CO2 or MNB + air.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of shallot-enriched amaranth-based extruded snacks to modulate carbohydrate-hydrolyzing enzymes and manage diabetes mellitus in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: The snacks showed high protein, phenol, and flavonoid content, improved hematological parameters, reduced enzyme activities in kidney and liver homogenates, and decreased α-glucosidase/α-amylase activities, suggesting potential for managing hyperglycemia and diabetic complications.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of amaranth oil and rapeseed oil on atherosclerosis-related parameters in overweight and obese subjects.
results_summary: Amaranth oil slightly increased adiponectin levels but negatively affected ApoB concentrations and the ApoB/A1 ratio compared to rapeseed oil. No significant differences were observed in other atherosclerosis markers.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese subjects
study_duration: Two consecutive three-week intervention periods separated by a washout period of the same duration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intercropping sorghum and amaranth enhances yield and quality of forage under limited irrigation conditions.
results_summary: Intercropping sorghum and amaranth improved yield and quality under conventional irrigation but showed reduced benefits under water-saving irrigation methods. Sorghum monoculture and S75-A25 intercropping had the highest irrigation water use efficiency.
population_specificity: Forage crops (sorghum and amaranth) in arid and semi-arid regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an aqueous extract from steamed red amaranth leaves could protect human lens epithelial cells (HLE-B3) from high glucose-induced damage, potentially preventing diabetic retinopathy.
results_summary: The aqueous extract increased cell survival, upregulated protective gene expression (Bcl-2, Nrf2), restored Na+-K+ ATPase activity and mitochondrial membrane potential, and reduced harmful compounds (AGEs, methylglyoxal, ROS) in high glucose-treated cells.
population_specificity: Human lens epithelial cell line (HLE-B3) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a magnetic nanocomposite (WS2/Fe3O4/CNTs-NC) in removing amaranth (AM) and brilliant blue FCF dyes from wastewater using ultrasound-assisted adsorption.
results_summary: The study achieved high removal percentages (99.30% for AM and 98.50% for BB FCF) under optimal conditions, with adsorption capacities of 174.8 mg g-1 for AM and 166.7 mg g-1 for BB FCF. The process was endothermic, spontaneous, and reusable for multiple cycles (>90% efficiency after five cycles).
population_specificity: Wastewater contaminated with dyes (binary solutions).
effective_dosage: AM concentration ranged from 10-50 mg L-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Raman spectroscopy could rapidly and non-destructively distinguish between glyphosate-resistant and -susceptible Palmer amaranth populations.
results_summary: Raman spectroscopy successfully differentiated herbicide-treated and non-treated susceptible populations based on changes in carotenoid-related vibrational bands, with detection accuracies ranging from 71.9% to 90%. Glyphosate-resistant populations showed relative differences in carotenoid concentrations, though these changes were not significant.
population_specificity: Glyphosate-resistant and -susceptible Palmer amaranth populations (three resistant, four susceptible).
study_duration: Measurements taken within 1 day (D1) of glyphosate treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how extraction pH and pH treatment affect the functional, physicochemical, rheological, and thermal properties of amaranth protein isolates (APIs).
results_summary: The study found that API P1, extracted at pH 9, exhibited superior protein content, purity, solubility, emulsifying and foaming properties, water and oil binding capacities, and thermal properties compared to other samples (P2, P3, P4). P1 also showed better gelation characteristics (higher storage and loss moduli).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on amaranth protein isolates).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pH treatments ranged from 3 to 9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the evolution of multiple herbicide resistance in the KCTR Palmer amaranth population and determine possible resistance mechanisms.
results_summary: The KCTR Palmer amaranth population exhibited six-way resistance to multiple herbicides, with resistance likely mediated by cytochrome P450 and GST enzyme activity, but remained susceptible to PS I- and glutamine synthetase inhibitor herbicides.
population_specificity: Palmer amaranth (KCTR population) from a long-term conservation tillage research project in Kansas, USA.
effective_dosage: Field recommended rates of various herbicides (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the level and molecular basis of resistance to the herbicide S-metolachlor in glyphosate-resistant Palmer amaranth (Amaranthus palmeri) populations.
results_summary: The study found that A. palmeri developed resistance to S-metolachlor as early as 2014, with resistance levels ranging from 88 to 785 g ai ha-1. Resistance was driven by elevated expression of GST genes (ApGSTU19, ApGSTF8, ApGSTF2, and ApGSTF2like) in roots, which detoxify the herbicide.
population_specificity: Glyphosate-resistant Palmer amaranth (Amaranthus palmeri) populations collected in Arkansas in 2014 and 2015.
effective_dosage: 1.1 kg ai ha-1 (recommended field dose) and variable doses in dose-response assays (27 to 785 g ai ha-1).
study_duration: Not specified (field samples collected in 2014 and 2015).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of amaranth flour and protein isolate on oxidative status in Wistar rats fed high-fat diets, focusing on intestinal and liver cells.
results_summary: Amaranth flour and protein isolate showed dose- and time-dependent effects on oxidative stress biomarkers, increasing antioxidant activity (e.g., GSH, SOD, GPx) in intestinal cells but mixed effects in liver cells (some reductions in GSH and SOD but large increases in GPx). The effects were more pronounced at higher doses (50% protein replacement) and shorter administration (1 week).
population_specificity: Wistar rats fed high-fat diets with added cholesterol and porcine fat.
effective_dosage: 25% or 50% protein replacement with amaranth flour or protein isolate.
study_duration: 4 weeks for most groups, 1 week for high-dose groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of home-processed amaranth grain bread in treating anemia, hemoglobin concentration, and iron deficiency anemia in young children.
results_summary: Processed amaranth bread significantly reduced anemia prevalence and increased hemoglobin concentration compared to maize bread, with lower risk of iron deficiency anemia in intention-to-treat analysis. No significant difference was found in iron deficiency between groups.
population_specificity: Two-to-five-year-old children with anemia in Southern Ethiopia.
effective_dosage: 150g bread containing 70% amaranth and 30% chickpea, daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Amaranth seed oil (ASO) and rapeseed oil (RSO) on weight loss and metabolic parameters during a 3-week body mass reduction program in obese individuals.
results_summary: ASO significantly improved fasting glucose, total cholesterol, non-HDL cholesterol, TG/HDL ratio, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides compared to RSO. Both ASO and RSO groups showed reductions in weight, BMI, and other anthropometric measures, with notable improvements in insulin levels and HOMA-IR.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (BMI > 30 kg/m²), aged 25-70 years.
